body:
Just tried that twice and it doesn't work. Thanks anyway. My forked repo shows a timestamp and new commit number, but when browsing the code no changes have been incorporated, and my pull request was also not updated.

Doh! Helps if I do 'git add' first. OK, finally got the process figured out and working after blundering along. Cool.



________________________________
 From: Matt Bridges <notifications@github.com>
To: rails/rails <rails@noreply.github.com> 
Cc: Adrien Lamothe <alamoz@yahoo.com> 
Sent: Saturday, July 6, 2013 9:51 AM
Subject: Re: [rails] Rails 4 update of 'The Asset Pipeline' guide. (#11326)
 


The only way to interact with and make pull requests from another repo you do not have commit access to is using a forked version.
Say, you have already pushed to master with your changes and opened a pull request with one single commit. You get feedback and make some changes without committing them locally. At this point. You can do this:
$ git commit --amend
$ git push --force 
This will update your own fork's master branch and the PR will be updated in the rails/rails repo.
Another scenario, you have more than one commit in a PR and you are asked to squash them into a single commit. This is where you follow @steveklabnik's post: http://blog.steveklabnik.com/posts/2012-11-08-how-to-squash-commits-in-a-github-pull-request.
You should never have to create a separate PR request unless you really messed up your rebase.
Hope this helps.
—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
